titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: Mr Pakenham the British Minister called on me this morning and I had a long and very free conversation with him, not upon his negotiations here, of which no mention was made either by him or me— He seemed anxious to know whether a special Session of Congress would be called as has been much rumoured but recently as if by authority denied— Immediately after the rejection by the Senate of the annexation Treaty Henderson who had come post-haste as Minister Plenipotentiary to sign it started post haste back it was said to prevent the abandonment of the project by the Texians, and to negotiate a popular movement there, still to cram down the annexation— I told Mr Pakenham, that I had seen with great pleasure in the Parliamentary papers of 1839 and 40. lent me by Mr Fox, the avowal by Lord Palmerston in a despatch to Lord Howard de Walden that to promote the abolition of Slavery throughout the world was a fixed and settled system of the British Government.— I had seen in the same papers the negotiations with all Europe and all America, especially with the Pope and the Bey of Tunis all tending to the same result— I told him of the visit of Andrews the Texian and of Lewis Tappan to me before they went to England last Summer— That Mr Andrews had communicated his designs to me, and I had expressed to him my doubts of his success. I had expressed the same doubt to Mr Tappan, and told him I thought the British Government would in this case sacrifice their principles to their policy— Mr Lewis Tappan without authority from me had apprized Lord Aberdeen of this opinion of mine, and Lord Aberdeen had protested against it but it had proved correct— The abolition of Slavery in Texas without war or bloodshed had been completely within the power of Great Britain, but her Government had failed to carry out their own principles.— They disclaim and concede too much. They parry carte and tierce to avoid the issue tendered them, and which they must meet— This was not the general character of English diplomacy. It was usually bold, open, explicit, stubborn— I could not perceive it in Lord Aberdeens disavowals nor in Mr Charles Elliots recent Letter to President Houston— Mr Pakenham took no offence at what I said, and spoke with much caution and reserve in return— He seems afraid of the English principles themselves, and fearful that the use of them would be to put edge tools in the hands of children— I called at Dyer’s auction room— At the Patriotic Bank, and at the Office of the Clerk of the House where I was furnished with a copy of the native American Memorial of A. De Kalb Tarr and 179 others with the names— I met Persico there, and he asked me to take him home to Fullers hotel—which I did— He afterwards brought me a bust of John Nelson, the present Attorney General, to look at his Visits from Mrs Carroll and Mrs Madison Cutts.

The heat by the thermometer has abated but the sultriness of the atmosphere keeps me still in a state which seems to myself like suspended animation. I sent this morning two blue chests N. 11. and 14. with the chest containing the documents of the 2d. and 3d. Sessions of the 27th. Congress, to Georgetown where they were ship’d in the Brig William L. Jones Samuel R. Davis, Master, for Boston— I made out with the help of my granddaughter Mary Louisa my account as Executor of the Will of Thomas B. Johnson, and took it to the judge of the orphan’s court. Nathl. P. Causin— He examined the vouchers and admitted them all, after at first objecting that a promissory Note for 150 dollars should have been sworn to by M. A. Giusta. He concluded to pass it without requiring the oath. I left my account and vouchers, upon which the Register Edward N. Noah is to make the Statement of the account in the form practised at the Office, and in which it is passed by the judge— I have kept the accounts at the Patriotic Bank, where I found this morning a balance in my favour on my Executor’s account of 626.63. which I drew in bills of the Bank— On re-examination of the account that I had delivered, an omission of four items with which I should have charged myself—two of them were on my bank book, but had escaped my attention— The other two were notes protested at the bank, and taken out and delivered to Mr Dyer for collection. I called yesterday and this day at Dyer’s auction room, but he was not there.— I visited also Mr Peter Force to enquire about the delivery of the 3d. Volume of the American Archives, but only ascertained where I must enquire further— Force had a bound copy of the 5th. volume of the American Archives; but they are not yet generally bound for delivery. And there is yet a 6th. Volume to complete the fourth series, extending only from the 19th. of April to 1774 to the 4th. of July 1776— He proposes then to take up the 3d and the 5th. series conjointly— I despatched my answer to Thomas W. T. Curtis of Rye New Hampshire and returned to him the mutilated copy, in Clara’s hand-writing of my vision— Did she give it away before her death? or leave it to her sister or her husband? why should I enquire? Miss Cutts was here this evening— There was a light thunder shower yesterday and a heavy shower without thunder this afternoon.— I took a short walk at evening twilight, but the weather is so languishing that I barely made out to finish a short note, for publication with my closing list of petitions for this Session— The note is on the memorial of A. de Kalb Tarr, and 179 native Americans, which on the 31st. of May the house laid on the table and on the 15th. of June took up and referred to the judiciary Committee.

Mr Lewis Johnson came to enquire if I had again spoken to the first comptroller of the Treasury concerning the remnant of claim of the heirs of William Otis— I told him I had been at the Comptroller’s Office to see him but he was not there— I proposed to go there again on Friday— He proposed that Mr Fendall should go with me, to which I assented, and he will request Mr Fendall to call on me at 10. Friday morning.— I settled accounts at Kinchy’s and Clagett’s. Saw R. W. Dyer who told me he had received the money on Milburn’s and Turner’s notes and would send it to me in the course of the day— I received at the Bank of Washington 90 dollars for the quarter’s interest on the Washington Corporation 6. per Cents.— Then at the Orphan’s Court, I added to my statement of account with the Estate of Thomas B. Johnson the 4 items which had been omitted, and took it to have it adjusted in conformity with the account as stated by the Register to which he then swore me.— At the Patriotic Book, I exchanged three of their 100 dollar Bills for an order upon the Bank of America in New-York. Then at the Office of the National Intelligencer I left with Mr Gales, my closing list of Petitions, presented by me to the House at the recent Session of Congress, with a Note upon the Memorial of A. de Kalb Tarr and 179 citizens of Pennsylvania, praying for an alteration of the naturalization Laws, so as to require 21 years residence for admission to the rights of suffrage; and a copy of the Memorial itself with the names of the signers and the endorsements of the Clerk shewing the first and second disposal of it by the house. Gales promised that the whole should be published in the Intelligencer on Saturday Morning, and I desired him to send me half a dozen copies of that day’s paper.— Gales said there was a new phase of the Texas question— Some new suspicion of British interference to abolish Slavery in Texas, prompted by Robert Walsh, now turned into a hack slave-driver, in one of his Letters published in the Intelligencer. There had been two Cabinet Meetings and it was the meerest chance that there had not been a call for an extra Session of Congress.— He said that Waddy Thompson was now here again.— He attended a whig meeting at Albany, a few days after the close of the Session of Congress; and there declared himself opposed to the annexation of Texas now and at any time— He is now at Fuller’s Hotel, and was hesitating whether to come out immediately with a publication in the Intelligencer, or to wait till his return to South Carolina— Gales told him there was no moment like the present moment and furnished him with several documents that he wanted; and he is now writing for publication— I walked after dinner half way to the race ground and back— My wife is confined to the chambers and my own condition is not much better— I began this evening an answer to J. Wingate about the statistical memorial, but shall not have time to finish it before I return to Quincy, and who knows what will occupy me there?— The blunders of the census and their consequences call for the bow and the shaft of Ulysses, and I have nothing but the telum im belle, sine ictu of Priam.

I had received from the Committee of arrangements of the Philodemic Society of Georgetown College an invitation to attend at 1. O’Clock P.M. this day at the delivery of an Oration by one of its members, and at an entertainment given by the faculty of the College, and the Society— One of my reasons for remaining in this city after the close of the Session of Congress till this day shall be past, was to escape from all the celebrations to which I was or might be invited; the noise and bustle and excitement and ranting of this day having become irksome to me. I intended nevertheless to attend this oration and entertainment at the Georgetown College, but my driver took an holiday for himself and disappointed me— I was however well pleased with my disappointment, passed the day very quietly at home till close upon Sunset when I strolled out for an hour, and on returning stop’d at Mrs Madison’s and took leave of her for the summer— Morning and evening visitors, as by the margin; chiefly military Officers, who had been in grand costume to pay their devoirs to the President— The wedding visit last Saturday and that of Independence day came so close together that the attendance this day was thin— Captain Tyler and his bride are the laughing stock of the city. It seems as if he was racing for a prize banner to the nuptials of the mock heroic— The Sublime and the Ridiculous.— He has assumed the war power as a prerogative; the veto power as a caprice; the appointing and dismissing power as a fund for bribery, and now under circumstances of revolting indecency, is performing with a young girl from New-York the old fable of January and May.— I wrote this day a Letter toBarnes and A. de Kalb Tarr in answer to that which they addressed to me with the memorial calling for alteration of the naturalization laws— It took all the leisure of the day and when written was too long. The native Americans are falling into the blunders of the abolition Societies. They have an excellent cause which they will ruin by mismanagement— The Native Americans, like the anti-masons will have a momentary and limited success; but the staff will break in their hands and lay them in the dust. My wife has been several days unwell, and is confined to the chambers— Rather unwell myself.

Mr Fendall called on me at 10 this morning, and I went with him to the Treasury Department where Mr George M. Bibb of Kentucky was the day before yesterday was installed as Secretary. Our business was with the first Comptroller James W. M’Culloh; and to urge the allowance of the remnant of claim for interest on the accounts of William Otis— His objection was that Francis S. Key, the Counsel for the claim, now deceased had chosen to have it settled without advancing this demand, and that it was now too late to go behind that settlement— He offered however to refer it again to the present Attorney General John Nelson; but intimated that his opinions with regard to the allowance of claims were far less indulgent than those of his predecessor the late Hugh S. Legaré— I went to the Capitol to return to the Congress Library all the books that I had borrowed there, but found it closed; the days of keeping it open during the recess of Congress being Tuesday, Thursday and Saturday instead of Tuesday and Friday as I had supposed— I left the books with Mr French of the House Clerk’s Office who promised to have them returned to the Library to-morrow— I took a few further Articles of Stationery, and the third Volume of the American Archives to complete my set.— French promised to send me to Quincy the remaining sheets of the Journal as they shall be delivered from the printers, and the diplomatic correspondence with Spain from 1816 to 1819 not yet printed— I called at the orphans court, and enquired of the judge respecting the distribution of the balance remaining in my hands of Mr Thomas B. Johnson’s property undevised; being according to the statement of the Register and to which I was sworn by him 492 dollarscents— The judge said it must be distributed between the five surviving sisters in equal portions, with a sixth equal share to be divided between the two surviving children of the eldest sister the first Mrs Hellen.— There being only a grand child of Mrs Pope living, by the statute of distributions no part of the property comes to her— Mrs John Adams and her daughter Mary-Louisa dined and spent the day at Mr Frye’s— My wife is much indisposed and confined to the chambers— I dined alone— Revised my Letter to W. D. Barnes and A. De Kalb Tarr, and struck out of it a whole page of red pepper very palatable yesterday, but flat, stale and unprofitable to day. Examined Mr Frye’s account, and drew up a petition to the judge of the orphan’s Court, stating the balance of Mr T. B. Johnson’s undivided property in my hands, naming the heirs entitled to it, and requesting an order for the distribution of it among them.

Mr Lewis Johnson came to take leave before my departure. Mr Fendall had told him the result of our conference with the first comptroller. I determined to postpone leaving this city from Monday till Wednesday next; partly on account of my wife’s illness for which Dr. Thomas is in attendance, and partly to finish as far as possible the settlement of Mr T. B. Johnson’s estate as his executor— I went first to the orphan’s court with my petition for an order of distribution of 480 dollars of the balance in my hands among the heirs of Mr Johnson being 80 dollars for each of the five surviving sisters, and 40 dollars for each of the two children of the first Mrs Hellen, the eldest sister.— The Register told me I could obtain the order from the judge at his house 11th. between G and H. Streets. I went there, and the judge entered upon my petition, an order to the Register to make out an order of distribution accordingly.— I then took my petition with this direction of the judge upon it, back to the Register, who thereupon made out the order of distribution which he sent me in the course of the day.— At the Bank of Washington I received Bills for 53 dollars 55 cents upon the check of R. W. Dyer which he sent me yesterday— At the Office of the National Intelligencer, I took 6 copies of the paper of this day, containing my closing list of Petitions, presented by me at the recent Session of Congress to the house of Representatives, with the note upon the memorial of A. de Kalb Tarr and 179 citizens of Pennsylvania, praying for alteration of the naturalization Laws. I enclosed one of these papers in my Letter to W. D. Barnes, and A. de Kalb Tarr; and one to my Son, for the long Letter of Waddy Thompson junr. against the annexation of Texas, and the annexation Treaty.— I met Mr Thompson at the Intelligencer Office, and had a long conversation with him and Mr Gales, on the subject— Thompson is a South-Carolina planter, owner of 100 Slaves, and religiously believes that Slavery was made for the African race and the African race for Slavery.— He opposes the annexation of Texas on Southern grounds as a Southern man— So did Calhoun—so did M’Duffie. So did Hamilton, all now rabid annexationists— Thompson will be converted like them. He knocks down Walker, Wilkins and C. J. Ingersoll with their own Maul. But he smuggled through Congress the acknowledgment of Texas, prematurely— He is as cunning as four yankees, as sly as four quakers, and just now admires the People of Massachusetts too much.— I hope his Letter will be eminently useful at the present crisis, and devoutly pray that he, and Benton, and the Princeton gun, may be instruments for the deliverance of my Country.

A new protestant Episcopal church has been built in our neighbourhood, called the Church of the Epiphany, under the charge of the Revd. John W. French, who was chaplain to the house of Representatives at the special Session of Congress in 1841. and since then has preached some time in Georgetown, and later here in Washington, till he has gathered a flock and become their pastor perhaps not in the most regular order of apostolican succession— They have not even waited for the consecration or dedication of the church, which is yet unfinished, but in which he performed publish worship for the first time, this day.— He read the morning prayer with the litany and short communion for the fifth Sunday after Trinity— He preached from Psalm 122.1. “I was glad when they said unto me, let us go into the house of the Lord.”— It was an elaborate and regular dedication sermon, in which he enumerated all the reasons which a Christian has for being glad when he is summoned to go into the house of the Lord— The blessing of constant and faithful attendance upon public worship— This is a subject upon which it becomes a man to be distrustful of his own motives. The pleasure of attending upon the ordinances of religion may be an impulse of self righteousness, any thing but virtue. Attendance upon public worship for the purpose of homage to our own maker is the bare performance of duty—for the purpose of receiving instruction and reproof is just and reasonable; for the purpose of seeing and being seen of men, is vanity and hipocrisy, for mere curiosity, is idleness; and for the purpose of carping upon the performances of the preacher is an abusive exercise of faculties given for self improvement and gratitude to God— Mr French preached without notes. There is no pulpit, and he came from behind the desk with frequent exhibition of his person—his gesticulation was graceful; his elocution fluent, his delivery earnest and impressive— He gave notice that he would administer the communion the next Lord’s day, but did not add the usual exhortation of the episcopal prayer-book to partake of it. After dinner at Saint John’s church, Mr Pyne read the evening prayers for the same day and preached from Psalm 119.18. [“]Open thou mine eyes, that I may behold wondrous things, out of thy law”— Mr Pyne is a very acceptable preacher— Mr Cutts and his daughter Mary spent part of the Evening with us—and Mr Charles B. King.

One of the greatest dangers in this world to a man’s moral honesty is the possession of money belonging to others. The temptation to use it as his own, is perpetually recurring; and when thus used it becomes at once a debt and a privation of the means of paying it— In my ordinary concerns I have upon an average three calls for money every day— If I have money of others at hand, and none of my own, it is so convenient to borrow for the present payment that the future call to refund is overlook and debt, burdensome debt is unwarily contracted— On making up my first account of the Execution of Mr Thomas B. Johnson’s Will, I found a balance of 503 dollars 27 cents in my hands undevised— But the practice at the Orphan’s Court is that the Register makes up the account in his own way; and he accordingly made out my account, with a balance of 492:78. to which he put me upon oath— I gave him notice that the balance of my own statement was larger, and that I should credit the Estate for the difference in my second account— To disburden myself as far as possible of this balance I concluded to pay off the portions due to all the heirs now here, for which purpose I exchanged the order from the Patriotic Bank on the Bank of America at New-York, which I had taken for 300 dollars and took one for 100 dollars, and the other 200 dollars in bills of the late banks of this City— I drew also the remaining balance of 58.43. of the deposit for Mrs John Adams.— I then called on Mrs Adelaide Hellen at her house, paid her 80 dollars, and took her receipt. Then on Mr Frye at the paymaster general’s office—paid him 160 dollars for the portions of Mrs Frye and Mrs W. S. Smith for which they afterwards sent me their receipts— I had already those of my wife, of Johnson Hellen, and of Mrs John Adams.— There remains now only that of Mrs Boyd, which I cannot yet obtain— And I still owe 100 dollars to my wife and 140. to Mrs John Adams.— I returned to the Department of State The two Volumes of Instructions to Ministers of the United States in Europe, and two printed Volumes of English diplomatic collections which I had borrowed last Year. I enquired of Mr Calhoun if any answer had yet been received about the papers to be obtained from the Province of New-Brunswick— None— While I was with Mr Calhoun, he received a Note from the President requesting his immediate attendance at a Cabinet Meeting, about the horrible and bloody riots at Philadelphia— At the War Department I requested the re-entrance of the name of Robinson as an applicant for a Cadet warrant. Mrs Frye and Mrs Smith were here this Evening— Walk over the Tiber.

I made up my second account of execution of the will of Mr Thomas B. Johnson, and without waiting to take copies of them, carried them with the vouchers to the judge of the Orphan’s Court, at the City Hall— The vouchers were received and the account to which I was sworn was allowed— There remains nothing further to be done but payment of 80 dollars to Mrs Boyd for the final settlement of the Estate—and the fulfilment of my trust as the executor of the Will— At the Patriotic Bank, I balanced my last account there—took a second order for 100 dollars, and a third of 62.50, for my wife on the Bank of America at New-York— I called at the National Intelligencer Office, but neither Mr Gales nor Mr Seaton was there— I returned home and occupied the remainder of the day in packing up for departure— Though I have ship’d three chests of books and papers to go round by water, and take two trunks with me chiefly filled also with papers, I leave behind a number sufficient to fill another large chest, and among them many which I shall most urgently need— My projects of employment for the remainder of the Summer and the next Autumn weigh heavily upon my spirits; with a deep apprehension that I shall fail to carry all or any of them into useful execution; and a profound conviction that the time for my departure is at hand, and that the preparation for closing all my accounts with this world cannot much longer be delayed— I had received a Letter from Judge Jacob Burnet of Cincinnati, Ohio and one from his son G. W. Burnet, who is going to Europe, for the benefit of his health— They ask for Letters of introduction; a request of the import of which the most intelligent people of this country have not the most distant conception— I wrote for Mr Burnet two short Letters, to Edward Everett, and to our Consul at London, Thomas Aspinwall— We further postponed our departure till the afternoon of to-morrow, to go no farther to morrow than Baltimore— The riots in the City of Philadelphia between the Native Americans, and the Irish Roman Catholics, have blazed up into a civil War, with this most extraordinary result that the Catholic Irish are invariably the first aggressors, and the civil and military authorities, are bandied in shooting down the Natives— In the course of Sunday Night and before day light yesterday morning; not less than 30 Native Americans and 8 or ten militia men were killed in battle array— There has been much mismanagement in the measures of the authorities to subdue the insurrection— Richard and Mary Cutts were here this Evening, and two of the daughters of General Jesup— The heat of the weather is oppressive.

div.dateline: From Washington to Baltimore Wednesday 10 July 1844
div.p: We had concluded to take the afternoon train of Cars, and to proceed no father upon our journey this day than Baltimore— We were of course occupied all the morning in packing up— We dined at 3. O’Clock— Mary Cutts with us to take leave— Mrs Talbot, confined to her bed by indisposition sent to me for an autograph sign-manual for Mr Bushby in England, and for a line upon a sheet of flower embroidered note-paper for herself— Mrs Thornton came in to take leave of the Ladies and sent me some lines of her own. At half past 3. I went in to Mr Parris’s and took leave of him and his daughter Sarah— Thomas Dumphy took us in his hack to the Rail-road depot, and at 4. P.M. we were seated in the Cars and started for Baltimore— My wife, my son John’s widow Mary Catherine, and her daughter Mary-Louisa, form our company, with my yankee friend Benjamin F. Andrews, and the mulatto boy Williamto help us— At the Depot we met Mrs Wilkins, wife of the Secretary of War, and her daughter, going home. General Scott and two young Ladies going to his seat in New-Jersey; but they were in different Cars and we saw no more of them. In two short hours we were at Baltimore, and came in a hack to Barnum’s. He himself died some months since, but his establishment survives, in charge of his Son— The heat kept us from strolling. I met Dr Semmes in the reading room— I received a note from A. A. Phelps of Boston, and afterwards a visit with Mr Gallagher a lawyer of this place, to consult me what to do for the Revd. Charles T. Torrey, in jail here, upon a charge of enticing Slaves to run away, and under a demand to be delivered up from the Governor of Virginia, for a like crime there— Bail might be taken for the Maryland Offence, but not while the Virginia bolt impends. I advised to take out a writ of habeas corpus returnable to the circuit Court of the United States—to bring the whole case before Chief Justice Taney and in the event of an adverse decision by him, appeal to the Supreme Court of the United States— They said so they would do— The case is unique. I told them that upon this matter of Slavery the Law of the Free and the Slave States is in direct conflict, and referred them to the cases of the Antelope and of the Amistad captives.

I enter this day on the 78th. year of my age; and but for a blessed dispensation of almighty God, it would have been the last day both of my own life, and of that of my dear and ever beloved wife. We both escaped as if by miracle, and neither of us unhurt— I rose this morning at Barnum’s in Baltimore, before the Sun, and after journalizing the day for yesterday, sent for Mr. A. A. Phelps, and had a long conversation with him concerning Charles T. Torrey in prison here upon a charge of enticing away Slaves from a Citizen of Maryland; and demanded by the Governor of Virginia to be delivered upon a charge of the same crime in that State— I enquired, what was the punishment for that crime in the two States— Mr Phelps said imprisonment at the discretion of the court, not exceeding 20 years.— I asked the opinions of Mr Gallagher on Slavery. I enquired if other, and more employed to argue the whole case before the chief Justice as the Circuit judge and then before the Supreme Court of the United States— He said that Reverdy Johnson, and M’Mahon had been mentioned. I thought that sound opinions on the subject of Slavery, and an undaunted spirit to assert and maintain them were indispensable qualifications for any person selected for that argument, and I recommended that the counsel might be specially requested to study and refer freely to the case of the Negro Somerset in Howell’s State Trials to the case of the Antelope in Wheaton, and to my Review of it in the argument for the Amistad captives— To Mr Baldwin’s argument in that same case; and to Lord Stowell’s decision in the case of the Slave Grace, and I said that having a great personal regard for Mr Torrey I should happy if I could furnish his counsel with any information which might be useful for his defence.— We left Baltimore at 9. A.M in the train of Cars for Philadelphia, which city we reached about 4 in the afternoon, and found yet in amphibious state between mob and martial Law— We concluded to proceed immediately to New-York. At 5 in the afternoon we left Walnut street wharf in the Steamer New Philadelphia and came to Bristol 20. Miles—there landed, and proceeded in the train of Cars through Trenton, New Brunswick, Elizabethtown and Newark to Jersey City— The Sunset between Trenton was glorious, equal to anything I ever beheld— As I witnessed the departing luminary, and the peace and quiet and felicity of all around me, I thought of Washington and Trenton, and the 25th. of December 1776 and a feeling of inexpressible joy, filled my Soul— Between 10 and 11. we alighted from the cars on an unrailed floor, raised about 4 feet above the ground. walking on this floor, dark as midnight, I stept unawares off the floor, and pitched over, and drew my wife, whose arm was linked in mine over after me. Blessed be God neither neck nor limb of either of us was broken— We were enabled after an hour of delay to cross the ferry to New-York, and reached the Aston house before midnight.

div.dateline:
New-York— Steamer Rhode Island Long-Island Sound
Friday 12 July 1844.
div.p: The sensation which I suffered last night by the shock of my own fall, instantly succeeded by that of my wife was such as I never in my life experienced before, and which I have no words to describe; while falling I had the distinct idea that I was killed— A shriek from my wife, and the consciousness that she too was killed had in it a thrill of horror of which I knew not that the human frame was susceptible. My fall was so disposed that my left hip first met the earth tip’d me over upon the right side and laid me sprawling, but neither my head nor my body struck the earth— I instantly rose, feeling pain only on the hip and that not severe—but the terror for my wife, no pang of death could surpass. She had fallen forwards. Her cloathing had protected her from any shock to the body, but her left wrist was sprained and the recoil from the ground struck her breast; broke the glass of the breastpin, and slightly bruised a spot on the upper side of her chin below the lip. She had fainted and was senseless. Several men came to our assistance— They took her up and carried her into one the house sheds of the railroad company where were benches to sit upon. A physician was sent for, but as she soon came to and appeared not to be much hurt that order was countermanded— The other passengers had crossed the river in the Steam-ferry boat, and that boat in about half an hour returned. My wife had then so far recovered that she was able to be led to the boat; we crossed the river, and a hack took us to the Astor house. They gave us two bed-rooms on the first floor, and before midnight we were lodged for the Night, still unknowing how much we were injured but grateful that our lives and limbs had been spared— After a restless and agitated Night my wife felt the pain of the blow on the breast more than last Night— The skin was not broken on my hip but the bone was painful and sore, and a spot on my hip and thigh as large as a common dinner table plate is crimson with extravasated blood. It was bathed with vinegar, but as it did not pain me much I walked out—called upon Mr Lewis Tappan, and had some conversation with him respecting the case of Mr Torrey. At the Bank of America, I received in its bills 262.50 on the orders from the Patriotic Bank at Washington— At the door of the Bank I met Mr Sedgwick with a passing salutation— On returning to the Astor house, the inflammation upon my hip was so exasperated as to produce spasms in the calf of my leg— I was obliged to lie down, and to have the part rubbed with cold vinegar— After an hour of rest I took a Cab and went to N. 122 Bleecker Street where I found Mr Edward S. Marchant Portrait Painter. He had charged me 200 dollars for copies of two small profiles of President Washington and my father— I objected to this price and offered him 100 dollars about double their worth for the two—which with some reluctance he accepted, and gave me a receipt in full— I returned to the Astor house. My wife—Mary Louisa and the Servants without waiting to dine came on board the Steamer Rhode-Island— I came on board after dinner, and at 5 we departed for Stonington.

div.dateline:
Stoningon.— Providence— Boston— Quincy.
Saturday. 13. July 1844.
div.p: Before I left the Astor house yesterday, Dr J. M. Wainwright twice called to see me. The first time I was lying down and did not see him—the second I met him in the passage just as the ladies were leaving the house to go on board the Steamer— I had time but to shake hands with him and part— The case was the same with Mrs De Windt, who was in the city, from cedar grove, and is publishing a book. Mr Charles Parker brought me a Letter of recommendation from Mr Lewis Tappan. They are raising a subscription to print 50000 copies of Mr Sedgwick’s Veto, of the Evening Post in pamphlets; and Mr Parker wants a commendatory Letter upon the pamphlet from me addressed to him. I declined, but took the proposal for consideration— At dinner at the Astor house, I sat next to Mr Samuel May of Boston who was going to Saratoga— At 5 P.M. The Steamer Rhode-Island, Captain S. Thayer left the Battery pier— N. 1— The Cleopatra, for Norwich loosening from the other side of the pier at the same moment— We took the lead little more than the length of the boat and held it till the darkness of Night parted us.— The weather was of the most exquisite beauty of Nature— We had about 300 fellow passengers, not one of whom did I see that I knew. Mary said she met and held conversation with Mrs James Lloyd of Boston. We had two State-rooms, each with two berths— I had scarcely time to remark how the bark cleaved the glassy surfaced waters of Long-Island Sound Sunset past 7. By dark, about 9. I turned in to my berth—steeped my senses in forgetfulness, and at half past 12 the bell sounded Stonington in ten minutes. We landed from the boat, scrambled an ascent into the Cars— Sat a full and tedious half hour; perhaps three quarter, waiting for the transportation of the baggage from the boat to the train of cars— Started at half-past one— Crossed the river by daylight, before Sunrise to Providence— Entered the new train of Cars, and as the Clocks had struck six—alighted at the Depot at the foot of Boston Common— We engaged the Carriage from the United States Hotel— Breakfasted at that house; and at half past eight this morning landed at my own house in Quincy; blessing divine providence that we are once more safe at home, though snatched as burning brands from the fire. My Son, his wife, daughter and four Sons were with us in a few minutes all well— John Kirke and his wife were also here to welcome us— The Ladies were so much exhausted with fatigue and 3 sleepless Nights that they soon retired to bed. I walked up the hill and dined with my Son and his family. I limp with considerable difficulty and some pain. Afternoon visit from Mr Quincy, President of Harvard University. He came from Cambridge to pass the day to-morrow, with his daughter Mrs Waterston. She with her husband, and his two Aunts Ruthven are here to pass the Summer, at the President’s Country Seat.

Neither my wife nor myself can yet ascertain the extent to which we have been personally injured by that terrific fall of Thursday Night, on alighting from the Cars at Jersey City. The shock upon her nerves jar’d her whole frame, and suspended all consciousness and animation for nearly ten minutes— The stroke upon the breast broke the glass of the breast pin, and the stricture on the breast is yet sore and feverish. She kept her bed all day yesterday; last Night and this day till evening. She sent for Dr Woodward who came, and applied leeches to her breast; from which she obtained some relief. The suffusion of blood on and around my left hip looks frightful—the pain is slight and passing away, but the cords of the leg are growing stiffer, and make me limp. I rode to and from Meeting, both parts of this day. Mr Lunt preached in the forenoon from 1. Corinthians 12.21. “And the eye cannot say unto the hand, I have no need of thee: nor again the head to the feet, I have no need of you.” This is in substance the old Roman Fable of Menenius Agrippa, which I suppose Paul borrowed from his familiar acquaintance with Roman history. Mr Lunt noticed as one of the striking characteristics of the Scriptures, that they deliver instruction, in the form of parables and fables— He noticed especially those of Jotham to the men of Shechem, and those of Nathan to David— They are undoubtedly among the most impressive parts of the Bible; narrative enlists the imagination—narrative takes hold of the sympathies, and strikes its roots into the Memory— It exercise all those faculties too in the process of composition, and is by all odds the most difficult part of writing— Mr Lunts discourse was an argument upon the mutual dependence of all the members of a community upon one another, and he closed with an illustration of his own, introducing a dialogue of self-glorification and disparagement, between the roots and leaves and blossoms of trees, which will leave the whole sermon fresh on my memory, and keep in preservation the didactic parts. Mr Lunt’s afternoon discourse was from Philippians 4.8. [“]Finally, brethren, whatsoever things are true, whatsoever things are honest, whatsoever things are just, whatsoever things are pure, whatsoever things are lovely, whatsoever things are of good report; if there be any virtue, and if there be any praise, think of these things.” A general exhortation to truth, justice, honesty, a modification of honesty, purity, another, loveliness, and good report—virtue and praise— Mr Lunt considered these several specifications in succession— He has improved much in his mode of delivery, using much more action, and animating his discourse even to vehemence. None of our Ladies attended public worship; and Mrs Charles Adams was confined at home this afternoon. Charles passed the evening here. My mind was not sufficiently settled to enable me to devote all the day to the most suitable occupations—

The fall at Jersey city, is yet severely felt, both by my wife and by myself; and still we know not how long and how far it will continue to be felt.— She is better this day; but still confined to her chamber. I am yet lame, and crippled, for walking. Patience, Resignation and blessing for the escape of us both from heavier calamity is the dictate of duty. In other respects, I luxuriate with delight in the tranquility and indolent repose of home— But indolence is waste and loss of time— This fable of Menenius Agrippa, stole upwards of hour of my time, in hunting for it, first in Livy, where, by the Index to the Bipont Edition Vol 13. I found it Book 2.32. and then in Shakespear’s Coriolanus, where it is charmingly dramatised in the first Scene— Mr Lunt paid me a visit this afternoon; and brought back the first Volume of Warton’s History of English Poetry; which belongs to the Adams town Library. Mr. Lunt had borrowed the 3. Volumes last autumn with the intention of preparing a course of Lectures on English Literature— Mr Lunt retains the 2d. and 3d. volumes of Warton, but has not accomplished his purpose of preparing a course of Lectures on English Literature. Well executed it would be a work of great usefulness; but it would be too large—too complicated— Warton’s history refers only to a very small fragment of the subject. It is the History of English Poetry from the close of the 11th. to the commencement of the eighteenth century, from 1100 to 1700. It comes not even down to the school of Queen Ann’s age— It is preceded by two Dissertations— One upon the origin of romantic fiction in Europe; and the other on the introduction of learning into Europe— Mr Lunt remarked that Warton’s subject does not embrace Shakespear, and although he does not wholly overlook the drama, he treats it very superficially— I observed that it would be difficult to give much interest to English Literature before the age of Elizabeth, but that a philosophical disquisition upon the genius and characters of the cotemporaries Shakespear, Spenser and Bacon would be rich in results— I spoke also of my published remarks on Shakespears Juliet, Lear, Desdemona, and Hamlet: and lent him a volume of miscellanies containing my replication upon the character of Desdemona— My Son came this afternoon, with four Deeds from the Trustees of Ward Nicholas Boylston’s Estate of lots of land in Charlestown—one to Andrew Hall, two to J. W. Whitten and one to Edward Adams—to be executed— I went with him this Evening to Mr Thomas Greenleaf’s to execute and acknowledge them before him as a Justice of Peace; but he said that although his commission had been renewed since it had expired; he had not taken the Oaths under the new Commission, and was therefore not qualified to take the acknowledgment of Deeds: so that we were obliged to defer the Execution to some other time— Mr Greenleaf was taking his new made hay prematurely put into the barn, out of it again, under symptoms of spontaneous combustion.

Soon after I rose this morning it began to sprinkle, so lightly that for nearly an hour I thought it a mere transient shower; but it continued and increased to a moderate steady rain till between 2 and 3 afternoon when it held up without clearing off— I was confined to the house by the weather and by my lameness. My wife was very sick, last night and all this day— Charles went to Boston, and returned home to dine. He and his wife passed a short evening here— My time is never tedious when I have my books around me; but there are so many and upon subjects so different, like baits upon a bundle of fish hooks, that I make after all, no profitable use of my time. After bringing up the arrears of this diary I commenced writing an address to my Constituents to give them an account of my conduct in the discharge of their trust— But precisely because this was the first and most burdensome task which I had imposed upon myself for the first moments of leisure at home, I found it insupportably irksome, and barely commenced and abandoned it— Menenius Agrippa and his fable occurred to me again and looked for and found it in Wrangham’s Langhornes Plutarch, and there I was referred to Dionysius Halicarnassensis for the most detailed account of the whole story. This I am yet to examine— I looked into the first volume of Warton’s history of English Poetry; found myself wading into deep waters, and for fear of losing my foothold immediately withdrew.— The charm of Lord Bacon was irresisible— I took up the first volume of his works in 5. quarto volumes—London 1765. and began upon his Life by David Mallet— I mean to pursue this steadily: a few pages every day. So strange a person—the wisest—greatest—meanest of mankind— Is there not instruction in every incident of such a man’s life— I see his relations with his father, Sir Nicholas Bacon Lord keeper—with Elizabeth and James—with the Cecils father and son, with Essex, and Coke, on the winding Staircase of human affairs. A short portion of this was a dose for meditation— After dinner in rummaging over the chests of old pamphlets which I would assort in some order, I pounced upon a collection of Documents numbered 155. dated Department of State April 15. 1818. and marked as referred to in the Report of the Secretary of State of the 14th March, accompanying the message to the House of Representatives of that date— This pamphlet contains the whole correspondence of the Negotiation of Charles Pinckney and James Monroe with the Spanish Government at Aranjuez from January to May 1805. concerning the claims of the United States founded on the Louisiana Treaty— P. 15 of this pamphlet marks the first assertion of our claim to the perdido, and the Bravo—page 20. proposes an article for adjustment of the boundary—p. 88. Don Pedro Cevallos 13. April 1805 Pinckney and Monroe answer 20. April 1805. p. 95. 98. 99. 100. Proposal of the Colorado—p. 105. by Pinckney and Monroe.

div.p: Still crippled— But I walked with my Son, to Mr Lemuel Bracket’s and there we executed and acknowledged the four Deeds of the Trustees of Ward Nicholas Boylston’s Estate, of certain lots of land in Charlestown— I deposited in the Quincy Stone Bank, the order of the Bank of the Metropolis at Washington upon the Merchant’s Bank at Boston— We went into the adjoining burying yard, where the family tomb has now my name now carved on a granite stone in advance over its iron doors.— There are already the remains of ten relatives of the family deposited there without any inscription—but on the granite side wall, there are spaces for two, marble tablets on which their names and years may be inscribed. I visited the monuments erected by my father over the graves of his father and grandfather his mother and grandfathers third and last wife. Of the first and second there is no memorial left— They are doubtless there. An unclaimed Tomb is there believed to be that of my great grandfather whose name I bear, is there, but no trace of him or his wife— The monument of the Minister has been repaired, and some of the inscriptions first made upon it. Norton Quincy only son of my great grand father, whose funeral from my father’s, now my own house I attended in September 1801. was buried in this tomb, but his name was not until the recent repair incribed on it— Anna Fiske, daughter of Thomas Shepard, wife first of Daniel Quincy, and secondly of Moses Fiske, died 24. July 1708 and was buried in this tomb, but her name is not inscribed upon it— Which appears by extracts from Fairfield’s journal, published in the Appendix to Mr Lunt’s two century discourses. She was the mother of my great-grandfather— During the remainder of the day I was idling. Resumed the reading of David Mallet’s life of Lord Bacon; which as it proceeds excites more and more of curiosity— The degree of his obsequiousness and servility to Elizabeth and her favourite Essex, and his subsequent treachery and cruelty to Essex— Then the baseness of his submission to James and to Buckingham— His venality and corruption as Chancellor and his ignominious abandonment of self-defence upon his trial—with his transcendent Genius, his overruling passion for the liberal arts and the advancement of Science, and his indefatigable application to studious labour there is a combination of qualities equally astonishing and painful. Unbounded admiration and heart sickening contempt; how can they be entertained at once for one and the same person? We had evening visits from the Revd. Mr Waterston and his wife, and also from Mr Beale and his two daughters Ann and Caroline— Mr and Mrs Lunt, were likewise here this afternoon, but I did not see them— My business was wholly neglected— I looked into Banier for Minerva and Pallas.

My wife was so far recovered as to be able to leave her chamber, and my lameness is gradually and slowly subsiding— I visited my garden, and nursery and seminary, but the winter’s frost, and Summer’s drought have killed so many of my trees, that I lose my interest in the cultivation of them— If it be possible to pursue with consistency any cultivation of plants, and be absent from them, from six to eight months of every year, I have not been able to discover the secret.— The result of fifteen years of observation and study of the nature and growth of trees, has not furnished me with any knowledge which I could turn to improvement in the art of raising or preserving them.— My Son went to Boston this morning, and after an early dinner, his wife with their daughter Louisa Catherine, their Son Charles Francis and Mary-Louisa, departed for an excursion of ten days, to Stockbridge and to Lebanon Springs. Mrs John Adams went with them as far as Boston, and returned with Louisa C. Smith who is to pass the Summer with us. Elizabeth C. Adams also came and took tea with us— She returned last evening from a visit to her relations at Portland— I finished reading the life of Francis Bacon, Baron Verulam and Viscount St. Albans, by David Mallet, prefixed to the Edition of his works in 5 volumes Quarto.— And I began the perusal of his works.— This man was a prodigy and a paradox— He should be studied as a Chronometer or a steam-engine should be studied— As a piece of moral and intellectual mechanism. Why did I not so study him fifty years ago? and of what use will it be for me to study him now? Indulgence of curiosity— A longing thirst for knowledge— A refuge from the sickening realities of life, and desponding anticipations of the future, may perhaps carry me through this undertaking. The general reflection upon the life of Bacon is the melancholy aspect of great vicissitudes of Fortune— His transcendent talents, rapacious ambition, and disgusting sycophancy combined to raise him to the pinnacle of opulence, of honours and of power. The causes of his downfall were his connivance with briberies practiced by his servants, and with whom he shared the plunder— But James the first himself, and his minion Buckingham were deeply implicated in the charges upon which he was convicted, and it was more of their sins than of his own that he bore the penalty— James remitted successively all the parts of the sentence against him, and although he had been declared incapable of holding any office of trust whatever, he was yet summoned to the first Parliament of Charles the first in 1625— It does not appear that he attended— He died at the Earl of Arundel’s house in Highgate on the 9th. of April 1626. at the age of 64.— He was married after the age of 40, but never had a child and his wife survived him 20 years— After the remission of his fine he was severel pinched with penury and his supplicatory Letter to the king for relief is agonizing.

Two young men, one named Salisbury from New-York, and the other Nelson from Boston, came out for mere curiosity to see the house— They were going away without enquiring for me, but I went out and spoke to them Salisbury said he had come from New-York, to see Boston on Bunker’s hill, and this house. I had also friendly visits from Mr John Whitney and Mr Josiah Brigham— I walked before dinner to the Post Office to despatch 3 letters and for exercise— But my thigh bone is yet sore, and the sinews are strained by walking— The extravasation of blood has spread downwards to the calf of the leg, and laterally to the left side of the loins, looking dark and threatening— The confinement to the house is tedious; I endeavour to cheer it by reading and travelled this day through the two Books of Francis Bacon, of the Proficience and advancement of Learning—human and divine— The work is dedicated to king James the first, and its introduction inspires a mingled sentiment of admiration of the boldness and grandeur of the design, which it announces, and of heart ache at the depth of degradation to which it sinks in servile adulation with which it besmears the king— It is presented as in the Nature and analogy of a free will offering from a worshiper to his Deity, alluding first to the daily sacrifices, and the occasional oblations of the Levitical Law—to which he likens the faithful performance of the duties of his official employments, and then proposing a voluntary superaddition of tribute appropriate to the transcendent learning of the king the wisest the greatest the most perfect monarch that ever sat upon a throne— And this was James the first! And this unparalleled royal learning should not only prove the glory of the then present age, but should be transmitted down to after ages as an imperishable monument for the benefit and admiration of Mankind— And this work was not the consummation of that mighty purport itself—but a mere outline of a plan to turn the royal cogitations to its atchievement— The stupendous magnitude of this undertaking; the courtly cunning ingenuity and meanness of suggesting it to the king as if it was an enterprize of his own, the lofty consciousness of its sublimity, and the sly implied disclaimer of it, as any thing more on the part of the author than a mere speculative hin to be moulded into form and substance are all deserving of profound meditation—of more than I can give.— He proceeds then to enumerate and to refute the objections against learning.— Of Divines— Of Politicians— As arising from the Fortunes, Manners, or Studies of Learned men— He discusses the Diseases of Learning, the peccant humours, which have not only given impediment to the proficience of Learning but have given also occasion to the traducement thereof— And he closes the book with a copious and cheering exhibition of the dignity of Learning—a theme upon which I follow him with delight.— The style is a continuous, and perpetual citation of classical and scriptural quotations. I rode this afternoon, with the Ladies, and little Arthur, as a substitute for exercise.

Rain again, all the former part of this day, which together with my sore limb confined me to the house. Mr. Cole is the Editor of a weekly journal, called the Boston Cultivator—and came to invite my subscription to the paper, of which he left one of last Saturday as a sample— I declined for the present alledging the multitude of Newspapers which I daily receive, as more than I know what to do with. We had some conversation about farming, of which he agreed with me, that a man absent eighth months of the year from his farm could know very little— In the Boston Newspapers of this morning, I noticed that the Brig William L. Jones, Captain Davis, arrived yesterday from Georgetown, and I sent Benjamin with a waggon to Boston, and he brought out the three chests of books and papers, which he had ship’d on the 2d. of this month— I made some progress in reading Bacon, on the advancement of Learning. Finished the first and began the second book— In the dedication to king James, gross as his adulation is, it is not random praise— He extols him for four specific virtues—a virtuous disposition, a virtuous ambition—a virtuous observation of the Laws of marriage, and a virtuous and most Christian desire of Peace— These were real virtues of James’s character, and they are genuine king-becoming graces.— and it is piteous to reflect that with all these virtues and with all that learning for which he was not less famed, his character as a king and as a man is universally despised— He was weak—

lg.l: Fallen Cherub—to be weak is miserable, doing or suffering—

div.p: For the fulsomeness of the flattery, I was seeking some excuse and it occurred to me that in monarchical Governments, this beplastering of the mighty man is conventional and formal; like your humble servant at the close of a Letter, or the greetings of acquaintances, and mere strangers, professing to be very obsequious to each other—meaning of course nothing of what is said— In the argument for the advancement of Science, I thought the objections, with which he began against it, were so frivolous, and trivial that they scarcely deserved the trouble of answering them. There is however something more forcible in the catalogue of the diseases of learning.— Hume speaks contemptuously of the style of Bacon— Its most remarkable character to my mind is the copious and original turn of his thoughts, with the incessant quotations from the bibles and from the Greek and Latin Classics.— I was not entirely satisfied with the life of Bacon by Mallet; and took up that of the Biographia Britannica, which is somewhat longer.— But the mode of writing with a load of Commentary always interrupting the narrative is intolerably tedious and incompatible with that unity which should be the first Law of written composition.

My wife was very sick all night, and I rose at 3. to light a lamp— She was confined this day till the Evening to her bed— I thought my wound was healed, till on walking to Meeting, I found it far otherwise— Mr Lunt preached from Romans 12.21. “Be not overcome of evil, but overcome evil with good.” This text naturally introduced some disquisition upon the nature of good and evil, and the old perplexing enquiry why a Supreme Almighty creator, wise and good permits the existence of evil— A question which can never be solved— The Book of Genesis in its account of the Creation says, that in the process of the six days work, God surveyed it in successive parcels, and saw that it was good.— But good for what? good for whom? Good and evil are relative terms, but their relation is not to action but to sufferance— Creation is an act of power— Neither good nor evil to the Creator. Neither good nor evil to the created inanimate—good and evil have reference only to sensation— Sensation is individual, and what is good to one may be evil to another— Life, is enjoyment, and therefore is good; but unless we were commanded to love God, I see no reason by the Law of Nature why it should be required. But the meaning of St. Paul in this passage is to advise the forgiveness of injuries— It is the concluding verse of the 12th. Chapter of the Epistle to the Romans, the summary of the whole doctrine of Christianity for this world— If there existed of the whole body of the holy scriptures nothing but this 12th. Chapter to the Romans, it would form the text of the most perfect religion that was ever devised upon Earth— Mr Lunt gave notice that immediately after the service of the afternoon, there would be an meeting of the members of the Church for the election of a Deacon, in the place of the late Deacon Samuel Savil. This was the first indication that I received of the death of Deacon Savil; of that of Deacon William Spear I had received advice some months since— I rode home, and to and from meeting this afternoon. Mr Degrand came out from Boston, and dined and spent the day with us. Mr Lunt’s text for his afternoon Sermon was from John 18.38. “Pilate saith unto him, What is truth?” He observed that perhaps Pilate put this question in a jeering Spirit; but he would suppose that of those who now heard him discourse some would with deep anxiety and sincere piety put to themselves often the same question, what is truth? And the conclusion to which after varied arguments he urged them to come was that Truth consisted in the firm conviction of the existence and omnipotence of God, of the immortality of our own Souls, and our responsibility beyond the grave— He closed with a very pathetic appeal to the hearts of his hearers upon this subject— The meeting of the members of the church for the choice of a deacon was held immediately after the service— The election was by ballot. The number of votes 28. of which 26 were for George Baxter. He was present and upon a call from Mr Lunt enquiring if he accepted the appointment; answered yes— Mrs T. B. Adams, Mrs John Angier, Elizabeth C. Adams and Elizabeth Harrod were here after meeting.

A day wholly uninterrupted by visitors; and much though not entirely confined to the house— The contusion upon my thigh bone is yet sore, and the flesh over it swollen; and it is angered by the exercise of walking— The extravasation of blood has discoloured the whole length of the thigh, and descended by the knee pit quite to the calf of the leg, creeping round at the same time upon the groin— All round the injured spot the surface of the skin is recovering its natural colour. But directly over the spot there is swelling, induration, heat, and slight pain to the touch. I have had some apprehension of internal suppuration; and Dr Woodward who examined the part on Sunday advised the application of leeches. Without examination, he repeated the advice this morning, but a diminution of the menacing symptoms, encouraging a hope of recovery by the vis medicatrix Naturae, I postponed receiving the visit of the leeches till tomorrow. I rode after dinner with Mrs John Adams, and Charles’s youngest boy Arthur round through Milton; and occupied the rest of the day, with the second book of Bacon’s advancement of learning, and with the life of Bacon, in the Biographia Britannica— The second book on the advancement of learning opens with a brief stimulant of flattery to king James, reminding him of the peculiar inducement to him to illustrate his name and reign by the advancement of knowledge for the benefit of after ages, inasmuch as he has progeny of his own, and a prospect of more, while his immediate predecessor Elizabeth, was a sojourner in the world, in respect of her unmarried life— He then proceeds to consider what had been undertaken and performed by kings and others for the increase and advancement of learning. Genius invents—talent combines, skill marshals, and judgment separates ideas— In embracing the whole compass of human knowledge, Bacon begins by dividing it into parts, and presents in a table the General Distribution of human knowledge— “The parts of human learning have reference to the three parts of Man’s Understanding which is the seat of learning; History to his Memory, Poesy to his Imagination, and Philosophy to his Reason—[”] The subdivisions of this classification are desperately numerous and complicated and after enumerating them he specifies upon each separate part of the system those which had, and those which had not before that time been sufficiently explored by human labour. It is not a little extraordinary that with such a range of intellectual power, he should have rejected the Copernican system of Astronomy, though he acknowledges that it accounts for all the apparent movements of the Heavenly orbs.— My progress in the reading of the life is slow, and painfully laborious by remarking the gigantic intellect and the moral obliquity combined in the character of this man.— The union of Power and of Virtue is so delightful in contemplation, that I shrink from the demonstration how far it was from being realized in the person of this great bad man— The present age is prolific of the depravity if not of the greatness.

Mr Curtis came this morning with his grandson just as we were setting down to breakfast. He came to consult with me respecting the disposal of a part of the Estate of the late Ward Nicholas Boylston— I had forgotten to endorse the order from the Bank of the Metropolis at Washington upon the Merchants Bank at Boston for 80 dollarscents received as unclaimed dividends at the Treasury and which I sent by my Son last week to Mr Curtis— I now endorsed it payable to him— He wishes now to sell the Estate in School Street and has an offer for it of 30000 dollars from MrSargent. But Mr Bowditch the Lawyer is of opinion that the clause in the will directing that the old hereditary Estates should be reserved by the Executors as the last to be sold, prohibits the sale of the School Street Estate—while the Milk Street land purchased by Mr Boylston himself remains unsold— Mr Curtis wished me to examine that provision in the Will, and then go to Boston and advise with Mr Bowditch concerning it; which I promised and if sufficiently recovered from my lameness, to go in to Boston and meet him at my Son’s Office between 9 and 10. O’Clock next Thursday morning. I rode out this afternoon with Louisa C. Smith, Mrs John Adams, and Charles’s youngest boy, Arthur, this day three years old— Miss Smith alighted at Mr John Greenleaf’s and there we met Mr Thomas Loring of Hingham— We rode round by Dr Storrs’s meeting house at Braintree, and on our return stop’d at Mr Greenleaf’s— He and his wife, my cousin Lucy are barely alive— He is 80 years old, blind deaf paralytic; and crippled by a dislocated shoulder by a fall down stairs two or three years ago. She is three years younger than me, and for the last seven years has been half a dozen times supposed to be dying, yet they live— Mr and Mrs Loring and Miss Beach were still there. Mrs Lucy Dawes, and Mrs. Mary Dawes, with her husband George Dawes live with them— I asked Mrs. Greenleaf if she knew any thing of the French Sermon about which I received a Letter from the Revd. Mr Miles of Lowell, but she did not— I proceed in my reading of the second Book of Bacon on the advancement of Learning, and of his life in the Biographia Britannica— The multiplicity of his subdivisions of the Sciences has already crowded my Memory into confusion— I should need a close study of a week to embrace them all, with discrimination— He advises the study of the Mathematics for a bird-witted child—that is who has not the faculty of attention— I feel dismally the want of this faculty, and believe that I ought to enter upon a course of Mathematics. The Life in the Biographia is more detailed and circumstantial than that of Mallet, and gives the succession of his works of his honours and of his disgrace. His Life embraces no inconsiderable part of the Reigns of Elizabeth, and of James the first— I drag along heavily one page a day, in writing upon the special subject which I had determined to discuss during the present recess of Congress. Mr Loring wishes me to go to Hingham, on the 1st. of August.

Mr Spear is an itinerant lecturer for an Anti-Slavery Abolition Society, and he came with a copy of my Letter to Thomas Loring of 8. August 1842. in which it is stated that the Slaves of this Union were then represented in the National House of Representatives by 25 members, and enquired whether this was the fact now. I told him that the statement made upon the apportionment, by the census of 1830. when the house of Representatives consisted of 242 members. But that the present apportionment is fixed by the census of 1840— The house consisting of 223 members— The standard of apportionment 70680.— The numbers of Slaves 2,487,213— The standard gives one representative for 117800 Slaves, or 21 members and a decimal fraction of 113. for the whole number— But as an element of power, the whole delegations from the Slave holding States, and each member represents the whole Slave-holding interest, and the whole mass of Slave owners— The number of their members therefore is not 21 but 88. knit together by one interest and that interest the ascendancy of Slavery. Mr Spear said this was a view of the subject new to him, and I referred him to my report at the recent Session of Congress, on the Massachusetts Resolutions for a further exposition of it— I gave him a copy of the printed Document of the proceedings of the Senate on the Texian Annexation Treaty— This afternoon I received a visit from Mr William Lawrence with his youngest daughter, and an inmate of his family, Miss Hale, and with them came Miss Harriet Welsh; who remained to pass some time with us— I rode with Louisa C. Smith, Miss Welsh, and Mary to Dorchester over Milton Bridge, recrossing the Neponset above, and returning by the new village of the granite quarries, and the Roman Catholic Church surmounted by its Cross— My double reading of Bacon, on the advancement of learning, and of his life, suffers interruption, by numberless casual and trivial avocations, of which when the day is gone I can give no account— I see frequent reference to Dr Rawley’s life of Lord Bacon, but the name of Rawley is not in the Catalogue of Harvard University Library. Dr Tenison, Dr Shaw, Stephens and Arthur Wilson, in a History of Great-Britain are also quoted as authorities for sundry statements of facts— Only the last of these works is in the college library.— My own work of the Season labours along more than any thing else. In the National Intelligencer of the 19th. there is the translation of a Letter from General Santa Anna the Mexican President about the propositions sent by the special messenger G. L. Thompson to be remembered— Matter for discourse on this subject multiplies under my hand and becomes daily more difficult to discuss.

I had promised Mr Nathaniel Curtis, to go into Boston this morning, to consult with him and Mr Bowditch about the sale of the Boylston Estate in School Street, and I have examined Mr Ward Nicholas Boylston’s Will to ascertain the extent of the limitation of the powers of the Executors to dispose of the real Estate— I find the words of the will are—the Estates which belonged to my Ancestors shall be the last sold. Now the Estate in School Street belonged to Thomas Boylston the third of the name in lineal descent including the first emigrant from England in 1636— He was not an ancestor of Ward Nicholas, but his uncle—brother to his mother Mary Hallowell, and Son of Thomas Boylston and Sarah Morecock.— This Thomas was the 4th. Son of the first emigrant Thomas. I find these particulars in a genealogical table compiled by Coll. A. S. Brooks 28 Septr. 1827. and copied by me 13. Septr. 1839. A question remains whether the Estate in School Street was purchased by the 3d. Thomas Boylston, or descended to him from his father. In the latter case, it comes within the limitation of the authority to sell— This question can be settled only by the title deeds.— I wished also to go in to Boston to attend the monthly meeting of the Massachusetts Historical Society But about Sunrise it began to sprinkle and I waited till near 9. O’Clock hoping that it would hold up—instead of which it came to a steady rain— I countermanded the order for the carriage, and passed the day without going beyond the yard— My reading was so desultory, and my attention so distracted that I retain nothing that I read— I had well nigh forgotten my Letters to Edward Everett and T. Aspinwall for Mr G. W. Burnet— I finally enclosed them in a short Letter to him addressed them as he had directed to New-York.— I received this morning a New-York Daily Tribune of last Monday, containing a translation through the New Orleans Bulletin, from the Diario del Gobierno of Mexico, of a Correspondence between Ben E. Green, son of Duff Green chargé d’Affaires of the United States in Mexico, and Jose Maria de Bocanegra, the Mexican Minister of Foreign Affairs: from the 25th. to the 31st of last May, whereby the Mexican Government was notified of the Treaty for the annexation of Texas which President Tyler had negotiated and sent to the Senate on theof April— I have also received two Sermons, one preached at the consecration of Bishop Eastburn, by Bishop De Lancey 29. December 1842 at Boston, and called the faithful Bishop; and the other by Edwards A. Park Professor at the Andover theological seminary, delivered on the 28th of May last at Boston, on the duties of the New-England Clergy— These Sermons, are the bane and antidote to each other. The New-York Evangelist of 11. July contains a narrative of a new expulsion of the Jesuits from Persia— This various and desultory reading absorbs my attention so that when I turn to the second Book of Bacon on the advancement of learning, my Memory becomes a cullender, and the stream of thought runs through as fast as I pour it in— Mary read this evening two Chapters of Coningsby— I suffered last Night with the rhumatism.

The confinement to which I still subject myself owing to the disability of my left thigh, affects my spirits and health, that seems to change my nature. The privation of that exercise which for so many years I have made a necessary of life, is sinking me into a state of Apathy and stagnation of the blood. I have every evening on going to bed an application of Opodeldoc, and my thigh is slowly and gradually recovering its colour.— This morning I began to work with the hoe, upon my seedling trees in the seminary—very few of which remain alive— Josiah Adams came to speak of a pew in the Meeting house which for some years pass he has rented of me— The year expires in October, and he wishes to continue the lease for another year I promised him an answer next week, to consult in the mean time my Son, whose return home to-morrow we expect.— We had morning visits from Rufus Dawes and his wife, judge Cranch’s daughter Elizabeth—Mrs Mary Dawes, and a Miss Fisher— Lewis Bass Collector of the Parish tax, brought me my bill for the present year 171 dollars 5 Cents—which I took ad referendum. A man named Brazee came from Brattleborough in the State of Vermont— Left an orphan in childhood, for the last 8 years he has made shoes for subsistence, but he aspires to loftier destinies, and is desirous of acquiring the Science of music—to qualify himself for teaching it— This of course requires expence, and he comes to me as a benevolent person to supply his wants— I declined without incivility— Evening visit from Mr George W. Beale— I rode this afternoon with Miss Welsh, Mrs John Adams and the child Arthur.— My wife has a Letter from his father at Lebanon springs, written that day.— I finished reading the second book of Bacon on the advancement of learning; and now I ought to compass the whole extent of the work, but cannot, without reading it over again and again— These two books however on the advancement of learning form a very small part of the Treatise de Augmentis scientiarum, which is in nine Books in the fourth Volume of this Edition, in Latin without any translation, and is itself only the first part of the Instauratio magna, the second part of which is the Novum Organum, like wise in Latin without translation— In the distribution of the Sciences and especially of those which concern the mind there are in this book a multitude of observations upon men and manners which would have been equally if not more appropriate in the Essays. There is in them a depth and compass of intellect admirable, and surprizing; but always some thing louche in the moral aspect.— The plan of the work is original; but the thoughts in detail are all borrowed; and the quotations from the Bible and from Greek and Latin Classics are numberless.
