div.p: Yesterday was the 47th. anniversary of my marriage. A day which I always welcome with gratitude to Heaven; but which at every return gives warning of nearer approach if not advent of the last. It passed away this time with out notice except in my memory It was a nearly idle day for reading or writing; and this day was still more so— I answered a Letter from Mr Henry Bowers of Scituate, and sent his two Portraits to my Son’s Office N. 23. Court Street Boston— Benjamin went in with the Carriage, and Harriet Welsh returned to Boston alone. In the Evening, my Son and the party with him came back from their excursion to Lebanon, Albany, and the Catskill Mountain All well. Dr Woodward was here, and examined again my contusion— There is yet a hard swelling at the spot on which I fell, and some discolouration of the skin by extravasated blood, down below the ham to the calf of the leg but the discolouration is fading, and the hard swelling abates. Alexander S. Johnson, eldest son of Mr Johnson of Utica, and of my brother Charles’s second daughter, came out with Mr George Thom from Boston; Mr Thom had an engagement in Boston and could not stay to dine— Mr Johnson dined with us, and after dinner I walked with him, first to my Son’s house, whence he surveyed the prospect of Boston harbour, the Boston State house, the Cap of the Boston Light-house, the upper part of the shaft of the Bunker hill Column—the background of the blue hills, and the side view of the Adams Temple, the rising granite town-house, the Hancock lot with the old lime tree in the centre, and the old cellar to the house where John Hancock was born, and the surrounding beautiful village—we then went to the temple, the door of which was open, and sexton in the porch under the belfry, and over the vaults. He had not the key of the vault where my father and mother repose, but Mr Johnson viewed the marble tablet, at the right hand of the pulpit as you go up the central aisle, erected in 1829. with the inscription upon it written by me, and surmounted by the marble bust of my father: the work of Greenough. Thence we proceed to the opposite grave yard, where my name carved on the granite front of my tomb, marks in advance the spot of my last home; and there we visited the four granite Monuments erected by my father to his ancestors Henry, Joseph Senior, Joseph and John who preceded him from the settlement of Mount Wollaston down to his own time— Mr Johnson then returned to Boston—while we were out Mr Robert G. Shaw and his daughter were here as visitors but were gone before we returned— My Son and Mary-Louisa came in at dusk of eve, and President Quincy, and the Revd. Mr Waterston paid us evening visits.

Dr Pierce of Brookline preached, this morning from a clause in Colossians 3.4. “Christ, who is our life.”— This figure of speech unintelligible in its literal sense was first used by Jesus Christ himself— “I am the resurrection and the life.” the life—not saying whose life— Paul, speaking to the Christians of Colosse says Christ is our life—and in the verse preceding that of the text he says— [“]For ye are dead, and your life is hid with Christ in God”—and the whole verse from which the text was taken reads [“]When Christ, our life, shall appear, then shall ye also appear with him in glory.”— This Epistle to the Colossians is one of the shortest books of the new Testament, consisting only of 4. short chapters, in which the peculiar Christian doctrine of the atonement is blended with a summary of moral precepts for the regulation of private and domestic life. Dr Pierce considered the assertion in the text that Christ is our life, under five several aspects 1. As Christ is the source 2. the manifestation 3. the hope, 4 the comfort and 5 the resurrection to eternal life. Upon each of these points he made remarks apposite to the text, but from which I could draw no very clear practical conclusion.— It was a dissertation of the old school of which Dr Pierce is one of the oldest patriarchs. A graduate of Harvard of 1793.— He gave notice at the request of Mr Lunt that the communion would be administered next Sunday.— He came home with me, and dined with us.— His afternoon text was from John 19.25. [“]Now there stood by the cross of Jesus, his mother, and his mother’s sister, Mary the wife of Cleophas, and Mary Magdalene.” (Question of construction, was the sister of Jesus’s mother, and Mary the wife of Cleophas the same person, or two persons, and if the same how came the two sisters to be both named Mary?) The motive for the selection of this text seems to have been, to pronounce a magnificent panegyric upon the female sex— I believe the superiority of the female sex in all the social and benevolent virtues, and am not sure that the tribute of the Doctor’s gallantry was out of place. I had scarcely returned from the afternoon service when Mr Degrand came in from Boston, with Mr W. W. Clapp Editor of the Boston Evening Gazette who took tea and spent the evening with us. They visited with me, my garden Nursery and seminary; and witnessed the ruin of my trees.— We had also evening visits from Mr and Mrs G. T. Bigelow, Elizabeth C. Adams, Georgiana Harrod, John and Fanny Foster and Charles Miller. Of course no reading. My Son also spent the Evening here

I was visiting my Seminary this morning, and for some bodily exercise was hoeing round the roots of my fruit trees dead and alive, when Mr E. Price Greenleaf came in, and walked with me round my grounds. I have lost at least forty peach trees of all ages whether by the frosts of last winter, or the drought of the present summer I cannot tell— Every one of the seedling Oaks of last Summer has perished— One budded Pear stock, and several Apples have thrown out vigorous shoots, but the borer at the root of the stock and the aphis at the top of the shoot prey upon their vitals in concert Mr Alexander S. Johnson came out from Boston in the Noon Stage to spend a week with us. After dinner Mr Beale called on me with Mr Gardiner, the chief surveyor for the projected Old Colony Railroad— They were staking it out, to pass within ten feet east of my eastern most barn—then to cross in oblique line the County-road—traverse centrally my lot in front of my house and the Hancock lot given by my father to the town, and pass close westward of the burying ground.— It would scarcely be possible to carry through a line more injurious to my property, both by the danger of firing my barns and by cutting up into fragments the most valuable lot of land that I possess. But it is useless to complain and idle to remonstrate. While standing out at the corner where they were to pass, a phaeton came along with a gentleman and Lady in it— The man got out, and came up to me, announced himself by the name of Cutler, and said he had been requested by Mr Henry Bowers of Scituate, to make enquiry concerning two Portraits of my father, and President Washington, which he had left with me last year, and he wished to know my opinion of them. I told him that I had received a Letter from Mr Bowers to the same effect which I had answered last Saturday, and according to his request had sent the portraits to my son’s office 23. Court Street Boston— And that I had been so much pleased with the Portraits that I had exact copies of them taken by an eminent Portrait Painter, Mr Marchant for myself— I met there also Harvey Field and John J. Carr, my tenant who lost a Cow last night, he thought by her eating whole apples.— A person by the name of Samuel L. Fiske of Southbridge in the County of Worcester, came and introduced himself as he said solely for the purpose of seeing me, and having to say that he had seen me— Mercy Tufts paid us an afternoon visit— And Mr Stockton the purser in the Navy, with his wife came out from Boston, where he is stationed and took tea with us. I walked up the hill to see Mrs Charles, who has come back from her tour very much fatigued and Charles came home with me and spent the Evening with us— Of the day thus occupied what can I say more—and what became of Bacon?

The preconcerted current of my daily occupations continues under great perturbation. My Son went to Boston this day, and brought me out a volume of critical and miscellaneous Essays of T. Babington Macaulay, consisting of reprinted articles from the Edinburgh Review— I wanted it for an article upon Lord Bacon, of which I had heard, and which I expect will be satisfactory— It is a review of a new Edition of Bacon’s works in 16 octavo volumes, published 1825–1834. by Basil Montagu— And in the last volume of which there is the desideratum, a new Life of Bacon— I sent an answer to Mr Daniel P. Parker’s invitation to me, to visit the ship which he has called by my name, and promised to go next Saturday, if a fair day. And I wrote an answer to Miss Thaxter’s invitation to me, to attend the anniversary celebration of the 1st. of August, at Hingham— We had a visit this afternoon from Mr Hülsemann the Austrian chargé d’Affaires at Washington; and afterwards one from Mr Loring, who was very urgent in soliciting my attendance at the Hingham celebration of the 1st. of August. I persisted in declining, assigned my lameness from which I have not yet sufficiently recovered, as my principal reason, but hinting at some others, not less monitory to detain me at home.— I told him I had answered with some prolixity Miss Thaxter’s Letter of invitation, and explained my unwillingness to take part in the celebration of this anniversary.— He said he should go to Boston again to-morrow, and on his return in the Evening would stop, and take the letter to Miss Thaxter and deliver it to her.— I began to read the Sylva Sylvarum, or Natural History in ten Centuries: each consisting of 100 experiments— There is a preface to this work by William Rawley, Lord Bacon’s Secretary written for publication before his death, but not published till after that event— He says it was intended as a third part of the Instauration. As a middle link between the De Augmentis Scientiarum, an the Novum Organum— But Bacon hesitated whether to publish it or not during his life time, and it does not appear at all essential to the great work. It is divided into experiments in consort, and experiments solitary; and it has more the appearance of a Cookery book, or collection of Confectioner’s receipts than a philosophical system of Natural history— It begins with experiments of percolation—or the straining and passing of bodies one through another— And the remarkable fact is that he falsifies the result of the experiment. He says dig a pit on the sea shore above high water mark, and sink it below low-water Mark— As the tide flows in, it will fill with fresh and potable water— This is a mistake—the water will not be potable, nor even potable though it will lose many of its saline particles, by evaporation. Charles spent the evening here, but his wife did not come.

For the first time since my return home I was able to go up the hill and see the Sun rise from the South-east corner of my Son’s house— My Chronometer is 51 minutes in advance of the Sun. It qualifies not a little the pleasure which I experience in witnessing the phenomenon of Sunrise to observe what progress of Southing he has already made from the solstitial point of declination. From this day forward the nights lengthen and the days shorten till the winter solstice, and I must soon rely upon lamplight for the morning hours— I received a note from Mr Loring, that he could not call here this afternoon, as he had promised yesterday— I took therefore the Letter to Miss Thaxter to the Post-Office— It began to sprinkle as I was on my way, and before I got home became a shower followed by others all the remainder of the day, which confined me to the house— Mr A. S. Johnson dined at Mrs T. B. Adams’s. I received a Letter from William Wallace Whitney at New-Orleans, enclosing the Morning Herald of that city of 17. July current— In that paper, there is printed a Letter from the same Whitney to William Cullen Bryant Editor of the New-York Evening Post. It is an elaborate and formal defence and attempted vindication of the character of General Edmund Pendleton Gaines from the charge of rashness in an editorial article of the Evening Post.— In his Letter to me enclosing this paper Mr Whitney refers to my address to my constituents at Braintree of 17. September 1842. in which he says I took occasion to allude to the measures of General Gaines on the Sabine during the Mexican and Sabine War, and as he, Whitney conceives, did him injustice— He therefore calls my attention to the printed Letter and requests a reconsideration of my opinion— The printed Letter is in so small a type that I was obliged to Mr A. S. Johnson for reading it to me; and it will require from me a calm, considerate and spirited answer.— But for this I must take time Charles and his wife and daughter spent the Evening with us.— But all my reading of Bacon is suspended, by Macaulay’s review of Basil Montagu’s edition of his work and Life. The review charges Montagu with a laborious and absurd effort to defend the moral character of Bacon; and the attempt to pass him off as a Spirit as pure as it was bright—but this was a desperate task. Macaulay darts into both extremes—extols the intellect and denigrates the moral qualities in Hyperboles. Bacon was at once an unscrupulous man of the world and sycophant of a royal court, and a profound philosopher— The important events of his life—his slow and gradual ascent to fame, power and honours— His horrible treachery to the Earl of Essex, his base subserviency to the favourite Buckingham; his lamentable downfall and self-sacrifice, and the resignation and perseverance with which he redeemed himself to the veneration of posterity are a theme for continuous meditation and unabating interest.
